awd_titl_txt: Magnetic Ionic Liquids as Tunable Solvents for Sample Preparation and Chemical Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) program in the Division of Chemistry. Professor Jared L. Anderson of Iowa State University is developing new separation media based on magnetic ionic liquids for sample preparation and chromatography methods. Magnetic ionic liquids are non-molecular solvents that possess low melting points, high stability, and can be controlled by an applied magnetic field. The proposed work will develop new advancements in nucleic acid analysis and have a major impact in various interdisciplinary fields including clinical diagnostics, biomedicine, and forensics. 

This project focuses on three areas where magnetic ionic liquids are studied and used in chemical measurement. Magnetic ionic liquids are designed and incorporated into chromatographic separations; new approaches are developed to achieve sequence specific extraction of deoxyribonucleic acid; and the preservation of ribonucleic acid structure is studied using magnetic ionic liquids as solvents. This research provides fundamental new knowledge about these materials and catalyzes the development of new approaches for achieving rapid and selective nucleic acid analysis. Graduate and undergraduate students acquire training in separation science and bioanalytical chemistry. High school students participate in the research through the American Chemical Society Project SEED program. A social networking program is used to disseminate scientific videos to young children and the general public.

por.por_cntn:
Separation science plays a critical role in ensuring the foods and services within our society are safe in order to maintain our standard of living and quality of life.  Developing separations methods and processes is challenging due to the fact that there is a growing list of contaminants in chemicals, medicines, drinking water, and food that need to be measured and validated in order to meet new and existing governmental regulations. In this funding, new materials based on ionic liquids and magnetic ionic liquids were designed and prepared. Ionic liquids are compounds that have many similarities to table salt, except that they are liquids at ambient temperature. The salt materials in this project were specifically designed so that they have high stability under extreme temperatures and that they can be easily moved or manipulated using a simple magnet. The ability to move the salts by a magnet provides them many uses, particularly in laboratories that seek automation where the salts can be used for a specific application. High school students, undergraduate students, and graduate students took part in this research project to use the magnetic ionic liquids as materials to extract contaminants from water samples as well as nucleic acids, including DNA and RNA, from biological samples. The extraction of nucleic acids is of particular importance due to the fact that they are commonly found in samples that are very complex; therefore, targeted isolation/removal of the nucleic acid is desired. In this work, an approach that enables the nucleic acid to be isolated from the sample while permitting it to be coupled to polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was developed. PCR is currently the gold standard approach to measure small amounts of nucleic acids. In this project, new extraction methods were developed to couple with qPCR to streamline the analysis and significantly improve the analysis steps. Methodologies were also developed to create platforms where nucleic acids can be rapidly extracted from a biological sample and the nucleic acid quickly amplified using devices slightly larger than a smartphone. Once the nucleic acid was amplified, a color change could be observed which can indicate the presence of a specific nucleic acid sequence. Students who worked on this project gained experience and training in how to operate sophisticated instrumentation required to measure small amounts of contaminants using the ionic liquid and magnetic ionic liquids. Additionally, they gained an understanding on how to incorporate materials prepared in the laboratory into methodologies that can significantly improve the analysis of small amounts of contaminants from samples such as water, plasma, urine, and plants. Trainees involved in this research project presented their data in poster and oral presentations at national and international conferences. In addition, their research findings were published in peer-reviewed scientific publications. Four undergraduate and five high student trainees were involved in this research project and pursued further education in undergraduate or graduate programs. For the five graduate students involved in this project, four of them took industrial positions and one accepted an academic position upon completing their doctoral degrees.
